Hirata Hikozo did a lot of work in copper alloys.  =
Most plates are yamagane or copper, but some are shinchu or shakudo.  Many =
of them are lacquered.  The mimi edge you're talking about is a fukurin (ri=
m cover) and Hikozo often used them, usually in a contrasting metal.  I thi=
nk that you're describing an Odawara fukurin, which was a particular specia=
lty of Hikozo.  Many Hirata guards have the concentric circle file marking =
you mention, but others have amida yasurime, irregular or polished surfaces=
.  Many do have a distinctive taganemei of heavy, domed punch marks along t=
he sides of the nakago ana.

I can't say what you have without seeing it.  =
There have been contemporary copies of Hikozo's work for sale at US sword s=
hows recently.  I don't think that they were made to deceive since they are=
 very obviously brand new, shiny and not at all in the taste of the origina=
l time and place.  On the other hand, a couple of them turned up at the Chi=
cago shinsa, so someone may have gotten a little confused.  I have no idea =
how the sellers are representing these guards.
